children.subject: I think the best thing for you to do would be to either schedule appointments via email or walk in for the office hours of the professors you'd like to talk to. Usually, faculty are quite interested in helping people like you out.
Professor Pister will be at Berkeley this semester! Seconded, he'd be a great person to talk to.

Dr. Pister is the perfect person to talk to. Ask about his SoC special topics course, and life as an electrical engineer in general. If he's not at Berkeley this semester [might be on sabbatical, do not recall], email him.

Is there such thing as analog circuit theory? Like using math to do things like harmonic analysis on an analog circuit, maybe a super in-depth 120 about the role of Fourier series in describing analog circuits in particular? Looking at the content of 105 and 140, the classes seem to be much more about building something you want given a spec and a set of rules rather than theory.

I don't know if learning this stuff (if it even exists) will get me a job in industry though.

Looking at Pister's and Niknejad's research, they don't really seem to be in line with what I'm personally interested in.

Yes! Check out the EE grad courses, especially people working on formal methods. I have no clue who the faculty is on that, and to get a job, you'd really need to do something like Krste Asanovic who incorporates that into broader research. Bernhard Boser or Kameshwar Poola might also be also be good people to hit up. 

Maybe even Alexandre Bayen as well?

If you’re interested in Analog Circuit Theory, then 105 and 140 are definitely courses to take, because they will cover just that. You’ll apply Lapalace analysis to Analog Circuits, and in a course like 142, you’ll even apply Harmonc balance. But you’re correct that a big part of all these classes is to design a circuit to meet a spec. This stuff would definitely get you a job in industry. In industry there are also roles in Analog Modeling, where you develop models of circuits to verify performance etc, but to get into these roles, you need the background circuit knowledge.  

I would also also check out 219C if you’re into formal methods, haven’t taken it myself, but it’s taught by Professor Sanjit Seshia

If you’re looking for specific course advice or anything, I’ve taken a lot of courses in analog/rf, feel free to post your questions below! 

Along with Pister, I’d also recommend visiting professor Ali Niknejad’s office hours

history.content:
I'm an EECS major currently very lost about what to specialize in. I know I probably want to end up in either comms/controls, analog, or RF. Who am I supposed to talk to in order to get a sense of the pros and cons of each of these fields? I was originally set on comms/controls, but I realized that most of the communications jobs in industry are not so much information theory and statistical analysis as much as analog/RF design. I now need help deciding what to do in the near future.

I guess I'm maybe looking for a peer student or a faculty member.

I know EECS gets faulty advising, but the ones I've talked to aren't super connected to the industry.

Ideally I would like to meet ASAP so I sort my classes for spring out before it's too late.
history.subject: Where can I go for EECS advising?
